aWH4ZKRXdKdqMpTueeqBtw.text: I ended up at Blue Hound after deciding we'd rather have a nice dinner than go to a Suns game.  Without a reservation we weren't really expecting to get seated right away but the hostess was great and was able to get us seated.    The service here is fantastic.  Our waiter was great and she was never hovering or too far away.  The food was paced out perfectly as well.  The food was very good.  We started with the fried green tomatoes which were served with a generous portion of crab meat.  I don't think I'd get this again though.  Don't get me wrong, I like crab meat but tomatoes weren't very good and were too thinly cut and for $15, you can do better.  Our entrees were the pork shank and the shrimp and grits.  The shanks was good and the fennel sausage and beans it came with might have been better than shank itself.  The shrimp and grits was creamy and delicious as well.    The cocktails were interesting and very well made so all around this was a great meal.  Docking 1 star because $125 for two people didn't really equate to what we received.  While everything was good, it was overpriced by 15-25%

22g3SmnHEIJwfgrP1Z5CFg.text: Went for New Year's Eve dinner after Suns game.  From the fixed menu my husband and I selected the heirloom tomato (truly excellent), lobster bisque (mediocre at best), filet mignon (mine-ordered medium but served well-done) ribeye steak (husband-ordered and served well-done) and we both had the lemon torte for dessert (very good).  As we were having dessert and coffee, tables around us were being set up for breakfast; lots of activity, noise and bumping of our chairs.  Outside patio chairs were brought in with door constantly opening and closing bringing in big bursts of frigid air and adding to noise and general turmoil.  Very disappointing for a meal that cost $270.00.

kkbx2rIupwwQ8730tBD4VQ.text: I was happy that this place was at the Kimpton Palomar hotel in Phoenix. The review is mainly on the drinks since, I only had an appetizer. That appetizer was the mac n cheese and it was scrumptious! Extra cheesey with a mixture of white cheeses, served in a petite cast iron skillet to keep it warm.   I tried three of the drinks on tbe menu, must try the hibiscus vodka drink ladies refreshing for sure! Meet Me in Rio was good as well if you like coconut milk nice and fruity. I also had a grapefruit rum drink that had a tangy zing. This place is a must if ever in DT Phoenix.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Happy hour mac and cheese with Meet Me in Rio drink!
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yummy hibiscus infused vodka drink

wgqR6XdzuARt3Z_Qh8wULw.text: I was very disappointed in my experience at the blue hound last night. We had tickets to see Andrea Bocelli at the arena and made our dinner reservations a month ago. When we arrived the main restaurant was closed to a private party. They directed us around the side and through the back to a small and cold room with no ambience. The menu seemed more limited them before and the specialty drinks that were on the website were not available. There were only two servers running the whole room. Our server never told us her name and when I asked her to explain some of the dishes on the menu she seemed surprised that she had to answer such a question. We had the crispy chicken bites which were not crispy at all, they were rubbery. My pasta was not brought out by my server and a couple of minutes later she came to ask how it was but I hadn't taken a bite yet. After taking a bite I tried to season it with salt and pepper but nothing was coming out of the mills and it really needed flavor, maybe some grated cheese. She never checked on us again and by the time I was full and half way through it was too late. The desert was some kind of pudding-also underwhelming. If they had sold the restaurant out for a private party we would have liked to know that and have the chance to go somewhere else.

bQm1_tca7LH2f7pyLqFx6w.text: I came to eat here based on the menu. I didn't realize it was a Kimpton restaurant, attached to the Palomar hotel. I'm a fan of Kimpton hotels, so I was delighted to learn it was one of their restaurants. The place is really cool - it's got a 20s speakeasy - library lounge type of look to it. The bartenders are even dressed the part.   I didn't have drinks here, just food. This place is like a gastropub, so everything on the menu sounded amazing. I ordered the deviled eggs, the tater tots, and the tagliatelle. The deviled eggs were all right - there was bacon mixed in with the yolk. Not the best deviled eggs I've ever had. The tater tots were good - they also had bacon inside and the inside had a very hash browny texture. It came with a dipping sauce, but that tasted weird. The tagliatelle pasta had roasted squash, wild mushrooms, in the sauce was a walnut pesto. It sounded amazing on paper, but this tasted really weird. And there was too much sauce that overpowered the pasta noodles and the squash and the mushrooms. I didn't really like it and wouldn't order it again.   Overall the food was just okay - it didn't amaze me. The food sounded good in theory on paper, and the presentation was really nice, but the taste and quality weren't enough to make me want to return. The service was good though. The hostess was really nice and friendly. The bartenders were adequate. And the food came out quickly. The best part of this place is the look of the interior.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Decor
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Tagliatelle close up
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Tagliatelle

YSgqOa-FPDokOfZTH3W7Lg.text: My last experience here was FAR more positive than my first.  I was seated promptly and the waitress made a point of asking if we were going to the concert at Talking Stick.  She wanted to make sure our food order wasn't behind a large party so we wouldn't be late - love that!    The cocktails were delicious and my pasta was fabulous.  Had we not had to get to a show, I might have liked to linger for perhaps another cocktail and maybe dessert.

sXc4sWJWlIWBnLe3tMxLCg.text: Beautiful, homey restaurant, and the food is great.  The service is attentive, and the seating is comfortable.  The drawback is the noise.  This restaurant is loud!  Don't expect to have a quiet, romantic dinner here, but it is definitely energetic.  The shrimp and grips is an amazing dish, but save room for the chocolate cake (it really needs twice as much of the marvelous banana ice cream, though).

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The chocolate cake, accompanied by brûlée bananas and banana ice cream.
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The shrimp and grits - this is the best I&#39;ve tasted outside of Charleston, SC!
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The homemade pasta with shrimp.

YBBzkToYW8QsKF0-YFrHdg.text: Basis for my starred ratings (which skews heavily to the food or drink): 1 star:  Never again. 2 stars:  Poor food, poor experience, extraordinary measures in order for me to come back. 3 stars:  Average, nothing really special, nothing particularly bad. 4 stars:  Very good, would definitely return. 5 stars:  A favorite, one of the best.  How much do I miss Chef Stephen Jones here?  A lot.  Since coming here from the first week it opened to my last visit last night and from every visit in between, something's gone missing from this place.  None of the food we had last night was bad.  The cocktails here are still very good and might bump it up to 4 stars, but I can't quite yet.  We ordered deviled eggs and boudin balls for appetizers.  The deviled eggs were filled with a bacon jam that was dry, inelegant at best.  But it all tasted fine together.  The boudin balls were filled with appeared more to be pulled pork than boudin.  I've had amazing boudin in Washington DC at DBGB Kitchen and some great boudin balls in New Orleans - these fell way short.  But again, tasted fine.  We got the chopped salad.  it was huge.  Almost too huge.  It is a heavy, heavy salad.  It's a riff on the chopped salad from The Gladly/Citizen Public House.  Dried corn for nice sweet crunch, lots of fregula for some chew and weight, avocados, romaine, heirloom plum tomatoes.  The dressing was a little heavy and every was just a tad . . . heavy.    Wife got the handmade pasta with some vegetables in a marinara sauce.  It was on the soft side of al dente, just shy of being overcooked.  But, as with everything else we tasted, it tasted "fine."  This place has lost its pizzazz.  The service was great, there was a loud bachelorette party going on but that's not a regular thing, and the food was, unfortunately, nothing to write home about.  We miss the old Blue Hound.  Hoping they can bring back some of the magic.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chili lime popcorn
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States

n401coovBE8a2rYo8YEMOw.text: I can't say enough about Blue Hound's catering service. The food was great and the atmosphere made my birthday super special. Brooke was my sales coordinator-she is a ray of sunshine to work with! She will respond to emails and your questions promptly and is incredibly attentive and focused on customer service. I cannot wait to book your services again!  -Ro

GAUh6SQZtXjxHHZ-zoKXsw.text: Awesome service, Sophie and Carolina were attentive and very helpful . Food, wine and hand crafted cocktails were superb. Salads were fresh, charcuterie appetizer was very filling and offered a varied array of meats and cheeses. Trout entree and pork sliders were excellent. Visited twice during our stay in Phoenix. Will be repeat customers when we come again.

mU1-Ipu5Edy9IeOemOnUkg.text: Was not disappointed at all. Everything was perfect. Loved the vibes,dimly lit and music not overly loud. I went for a GNO but definitely will be back for date nite. The cocktails omaggghh there is definitely thought and effort put in the drink menu. The food was excellent. Shrimp and grits and the pork shank.

pmzSX1npiReYoKRRV4g1cQ.text: I just landed in Phoenix for a few days, and since this is my very first time I wanted to kick it off with some good food.  After looking around on yelp, I found that this promising restaurant is in my very own hotel, so I figured what better way to start my trip than with some nice smoked meat.  The pulled pork on the menu seemed like the thing for me, but as I was talking to the waiter he mentioned that their burger was just voted the best in Phoenix.  I asked and he said that they grind their own meat.  So, never being one to turn down a good burger, I figured that would be a great start.  After the fact, I realize the fatal flaw in my plan was that I never asked if Phoenix was known for it's burgers...  I ordered an iced tea, and a burger (rare) with an over-easy egg on top.  Here are the details:  First, the iced tea is not very good as far as iced tea goes.  I asked the first server (not my waiter) if it was fresh brewed before I ordered it, and he said yes.  However, what came was a cloudy, bitter, iced tea that usually indicates that it came from a mix, or concentrate.  Second, my first burger arrived (yes, first).  Normally, I don't send food back, but it was REALLY SALTY. My lips were burning after the first bite. Beyond that, it was cooked medium or medium well.  I don't honestly know the difference when it gets that cooked.  It was chewy though.  Third, my second burger arrived.  It was seasoned well, but still overcooked.  It was dry and chewy.  Even the egg didn't make it better.  Maybe it would be good for someone who likes their burgers more well-done.  The bacon was good though.  Overall, I think they probably pre-cook their burgers and then heat them up to serve, as that would explain why they can't cook them to order.  The service was good.  I liked my waiter, and the manager did ask if he could bring me anything else, but I learned long ago not to go for a third try.  So, the two stars is not for the service, it is for the food.

BfLuxZjZwYBhavHhaPDmow.text: Well I've stayed too many times at the Kimpton to not have eaten here. But we try to avoid it.   Food is not bad but it's not great, it definitely satisfies hunger.   The staff has a bit of a snooty attitude, especially when you tell the the truth when they ask how your meal was. Response " could have been better". Maybe I rubbed them the wrong way but I'm not going to lie about how I was not satisfied with the way the food tasted.   Drinks are ok  Breakfast is decent, please just stick to the waffles/pancakes (something safe) and you will have a good breakfast.

XAdFULnQ3HumICSxYQdqfw.text: I came in for late night cocktails and was blown away by the quality and the professionalism of the staff. The cocktails are very well-conceived and nothing you could expect to find anywhere else, and even their takes on classics go above and beyond. They have a wide selection of high-quality spirits, and the bartenders are very competent and willing to meet you where you're at. If you want to stick with a classic you know and love, they'll hit it out of the park. If you want to try something for the first time and just have them make something up, they'll hit it out of the park.  The only cautionary notes I would throw out is that the place is not a bargain, and it's a bit... fancy. I rode my bike in and felt pretty out of place in tennis shoes and jeans. (An important note, though, the bartenders were still more than friendly and professional.)  tl;dr Come here to experience fine cocktails in a classy setting made by friendly, savvy bartenders. And if you're gonna be fancy, get fancy.  Also! If you're a Bourbon Fan, they have a specialty cocktail that incorporates the smoke of pipe tobacco. My friends and I are still talking about it a week later!

Vlpv55YDY9feN2OR-bslmw.text: Really liking the vibe here.  I like how the bar and lobby start to blend with a full house.  It is definitely a cocktail joint and the beer on tap continues to grow.  Have been about twice a week since they opened.  The food offers a wide variety to choose from and I like that many of the apps and entrees are created for a sharing environment. I've worked my way thru the menu pretty quickly.  Here's some suggestions:  *Starters* Tater Tots Deviled Eggs Warm Mixed Nuts Citrus Olives  Roasted Beets Heirloom Tomato Salad (Tasty, but 3 slices was not worth the price)  *Main Dishes* Mac N Chees Short Ribs     (The gravy boat dish is cool, but the rib needs to be cut into smaller pieces)  *Dessert* Cheese Cake with Tortilla Ice Cream    I'm not the biggest fan of dairy, but Tortilla Ice Cream is great!  All in all, I'm happy with the cocktails and apps at any hour.  You do pay for the upscale environment to be downtown, but I feel it's worth the experience.  The elevated view out of the windows is a spectacular over the city.  The biggest perk is you can head upstairs to Lustre's rooftop bar for a night cap.  You'll see a lot of the same staff working both bars.  I recommend for anyone especially the Scottsdale crowd before catching a game

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cheese Cake with Tortilla Ice Cream
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Menu
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Looking into the bar

lqnQQMutHUC3apT5wgK_gg.text: Great "comfort food". The pork shank is phenomenal (and huge!) and literally falls off the bone. The cheddar/bacon burger is perhaps the best burger I've had in the past year.

GDGe5djK5qVf6Y6h1CfN2g.text: Still needs work and I had the misfortune of  being a Guinea pig to the main course.  I loved all the appetizers I ordered and was excited to have the short rib and grits.  Unfortunately the short rib was all fat,  I took two bites of the short rib hoping it would get better., it was pure white fat.  I felt sick from eating it and was asked if I would like another rib.  Unfortunately after eating two pieces I was grossed out from the fat.   I also was offered 10 percent off my tab for the short rib?  I only had two bites and got 10 percent off?? I was honestly angry at that point, I did not eat it, they took it away, and now I am going to pay for it?  Luckily the manager corrected the bill and said it was a miss communication between him and the server.    Maybe after the corrections to the menu and items offered this will be a great place to eat.  After being subjected to the most fat consumed in 2 bites I am going to pass on this place and wait it out.  Hopefully some other Yelpers can try out new menu items so I am not the test subject for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Short rib cut open.  I took bites of the white fat and was done for the rest of the night.  The fat should of been removed??

4norcc1-4w5IHhxNMKwvnQ.text: This was our fourth visit to the Blue Hound. The first visit was for dinner and all subsequent visits were for cocktails only. Dinner here is sub-par. The drinks, however, are excellent. Whatever your poison - beer, wine or mixed drinks - this place carries a nicely curated selection of all things alcohol. The barkeeps are knowledgeable - and can whip up a really good Old Fashioned or a Sidecar without any fuss. Highly recommended for drinks not dinner. The happy hour food menu is average.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Nice selection of booze for your boozey evenings.
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shishito Peppers with some generic aioli - and an Old Fashioned.
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Caramel corn with chili flakes coupled with a nice glass of Pinot Grigio.

Q8MLVs2uFV0CXCw04amDig.text: I found that their HH menu contains a lot of spicier fare which I am not a fan of and its a limited menu at that.  The cocktails however are delicious still a bit pricey.  Sitting out on the patio is better than being indoors IMO.

hPbmv0wsp6bLqNdgiHIq6w.text: Heaven. This was recommended to us by a local as the 'not-to-be-missed'. We were surprised to find such a gem in the midst of a million spots near the convention center. Recommend the deviled eggs and shishito peppers for appetizers. BLT, crab cake, and fried moz salad. Try the High Heaven and Outlaw for cocktails. Perfect perfect perfect service. Tip: book through Open Table to insure a spot. You will love it.

uHXJSFjlCDZ_wawnWGljoA.text: Pretty yummy and really great atmosphere. I'm not much of a dessert person but the pineapple upside down cake was awesome. Also the fried green tomatoes with lump crab were delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Short rib sliders with braised onions and horseradish cream!
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States

hsi8n-m_9OL8GZIUk21Iyg.text: Took one bite of the sliders and it tasted like I poured half the salt shaker down my. Luther. Additionally they were oily and dry. My boyfriend took a bite of them and immediately commented on the extent of how bad they were. The salad was also overly salty. The corn grits were not to my liking. Cool ambience but the food sucked and I wouldn't recommend it in a city with such great restaurants.

rYdzIB2DK6qckWZqyetK4w.text: A friend and I came here as part of his birthday celebration.  After walking all the way around the block from Charming Charlie, entering the Hotel Palomar and taking the elevator to the second floor, we entered the bar... only to find we could have just exited Charming Charlie and walked right across the courtyard to a second entrance!  The bar was hopping, so we snagged one of the last seating areas - directly across from the host stand.  We sat on leather ottomans and waited for our waitress.  The waitress appeared within a couple minutes and grabbed us a bar menu.  We looked at the menu for several minutes before deciding on:  me - Queen's Park Swizzle him - Brown Derby  The Queen's Park Swizzle was like the Mexican Flag colored version of a mojito.  It was good, but not great.  That said, it was pretty strong.  The Brown Derby was delicious, with just the right hint of citrus.  Our cocktails were $8 each before tax and tip, so we stopped at one each.  Besides, we had a birthday night schedule to stick to!    In this area of town, there are a lot of choices.  Blue Hound won't likely be one of mine.    I could be convinced to try out their happy hour, but I don't know that I'd stick around for the food.  This place is a little too... uhhh... "hip" for me.  I actually HATED the artwork and the seating was uncomfortable.  The lighting was pretty cool, though (check out the pictures I snapped).  Overall, I'd say I was teetering between a 3 and 4... but I chose to award the place 3 stars because my cocktail was not spectacular for the price.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cool lighting
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Swizzle and Brow Derby

RG5trzHtPIPowV194o7HRw.text: An absolutely foodie's heaven - loved everything about this restaurant - the decor, the service, the imaginative menu, the cocktails (oh! the cocktails!!!) - all top notch...  Wouldn't hesitate to recommend and we will definitely be back :-)

3Ko7xYadADGDglogoYIoYg.text: We've been here twice now and it just keeps getting better. The first time was drinks and appetizers before a show and it was so great we had to come back. Danny was our waiter tonight and he definitely did not disappoint!! On top of the food being amazing he was always right on top of things. My son's water was never empty, our food was prompt and steaming hot, and he even noticed the small details like the missing orange in my Blue Hound special Hefeweizen without me having to say a word. I would absolutely recommend the Blue Hound and if you get the chance ask for Danny, you won't be disappointed.

aqIH5ccODu3JEa2DjyVEwg.text: Interesting menu. Drinks way over priced. Bone in pork belly was ok. Not enough to eat $12 vodka.  Would go back to try something else  H

IGL4ZpHZhu8aS1eZMI2u3w.text: I am not worthy to write a review.  Chief Currid I am a fan and am sure that one day you will be recognized for your superb receipes a and plate presentations. Server Jeremy you are the cherry on the cake!!   It is a sin if you do not eat here.  By far this is the best place.

m1JF2gjm3Mo8RiDY7XADEw.text: Order their Old Fashioned.  And the tater tots.   Trendy? Hipster, even? Who gives a....? The bartenders are the most attentive I've seen, and I appreciate watching them craft some of the finest cocktails I've had in Phoenix.   Try this place - you won't be disappointed.  From the moment you walk in, you can tell the folks here love their jobs.

XJBItin81A6nEhjW0_zpUA.text: Hmm, where to start....  Walking in, was greeted by a friendly hostess and place has a modern/rustic feel which I enjoyed.  I ordered a Bloody Mary to start and it was pretty good.  Had good spice to it, wasn't too heavy on the tomato juice side. Good flavor and simple, didn't come with an entire salad bar which I don't care for so that was a plus.     For the food: I ordered the chicken and waffles. While they weren't bad there definitely wasn't anything special either.  Overall they just lacked flavor.  If you've had LoLos before these do not even come close.  Just bland over all.  To me the best thing on the plate that had the most flavor was the syrup.     Service was good so no complaints there.  While I would give this place one more chance I wouldn't order the same thing again.  It is on the pricey side so I guess I expected more a punch for the price.     If you do come I'd say perhaps temper any expectations you may have and just take it as it is.

cAU2Ak9Lfntn9DW49usKng.text: Wow, I am impressed.  The bartenders are always amazing.  The manager was very flexible and accomidating for my larger group of friends. Their happy hour blows my hair back every time and the twist on a traditional old fashion was superb. :)

zglczAMsVP2gvhVk179iTQ.text: Bar is really busy on the weekends even when it is cold outside.  It has a nice patio though that looks over a pretty courtyard that houses an ice skating rink in the winter in the middle of the skyscrapers.  It feels like a little bit of NYC in the middle of Phoenix.    Bar is western/miner themed.  Crowd is more middle aged/mature.  Not a fancy bar, it is surprisingly on the casual side for the professional area it is in.  Drinks were pretty good.  Bartenders' skills are pretty high here.  Selection of alcohol is outstanding.

jdrBZUk8ZMNHx3inbbPXxA.text: One of the best meals we have ever had!  The ribeye was amazing!  Great service at the bar and Gena was a phenomenal server!

o_cnYO01osp-JbP9rdnMWA.text: I had lunch here on a Sunday and it was fantastic! The atmosphere was great, our server, Mike, was very nice with a great sense of humor. I had the seared tuna salad and I can honestly say it was by far the best I've ever had. It has a very unique flavor, not the typical salad. Had I been staying in town another day, I would have absolutely gone back and had it again!  My son had the turkey club which he also enjoyed. The fries that came with the sandwich were so freaking good. They were super crispy on the outside but almost airy/hollow on the inside.  Uh oh, I'm starting to drool...

Ud7LLVEJJ_AowrqW94djCg.text: Fortunately we had a dinner reservation the night we came.   The bar area was packed and the hostess was telling people it would be 3 hours for a table.   There were empty tables in the dining area during our meal so the 3 hour wait seemed incorrect.  Maybe she meant 3 hours to get a table in the bar?     We really enjoyed our food.  The staff was friendly and efficient.   We had:   - The BHKC Chop - Full of textures and flavors - Local Mixed Greens - Overdressed even for my husband's taste which means it had far too much dressing on it  - Pappardelle - rich and hearty - Blackened salmon - A little too salty but when eaten with the celery root puree it was very good   - Apple pie - wonderful!  It was noisy meal due to the busy, large bar area.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Papperdelle
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Apple pie - must order!
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chopped Salad

0ug2qiQIpKA1zN0YxUzqCA.text: Went to this place for the Christmas pop-up. When we were walking in, there was a sign that said "entrance on patio" I asked about it and a girl in red pants was extremely inconvenienced by my confusion and even more rude showing me where to go. Once we got in, there was no where to sit. Finally, some seats at the bar opened up and the couple sitting there offered their seats to us. The bartender would not let us sit there and had the seats removed. He said they were removing the seats for more space for standers. Fast forward about fifteen minutes and half our drinks gone, a party of four comes in just as a party is leaving. The arriving party was offered the seats by the departing party. The SAME bartender who denied us seats and even had them removed, let the arriving party sit and even continued to serve them! Seems like he was okay with anyone and everyone sitting except us. Bad experience from the time we were walking in, greeted by the rude girl with red pants. Wanted to enjoy this place but didn't.

sZTDcWnEBz6U4eQjIdOSQw.text: I have been to this bar two times in the last week. Last night we came for dinner, we gave the gal our name and number and she told us it would be about 30 min. We went to a nearby place for a drink because their bar was packed. After an hour no one text to say our table was ready so we waited another 20 minutes and decided to bail and had dinner elsewhere. Everyone in our party wanted to see the pop up bar so we headed back to the bar where we had the worse drinks! My husband asked for Sapphire gin and we watched her pour some random gin, I asked for a splash of cranberry and got half of a glass. Bartenders need a training on how to make drinks at this bar. We also never received a text or call about our table!

6Sed-aszOJx5m3vhQaMFtA.text: We stopped here by recommendation of Royce K. The hostess was on the phone and did not acknowledge us, but Nicolette stopped by and noticed it, she offered to assist us and answered our questions. We were specifically looking for a ribeye, and they did not have any, so we left. We were looking for a place within walking distance of Hilton Garden Inn Downtown. We did not find a good option for ribeye, but since Nicolette had mentioned a New York strip special they had, we decided to go back.  (I quickly made a reservation through my phone and we were seated right away, earlier we had been told the main dining area was quite busy and we were encouraged to sit at the bar, but with the reservation we were able to sit at the dining area... In a very weird corner and they were not even busy) As it turns out Nicolette was our server and she took really good care of us, from the brief interaction earlier we already knew she was going to be great. Hubby had a Long Island Iced Tea that was served in a super skinny tall glass with of course big ice cubes, so the portion was very small (not so happy about that detail), but then our dinner arrived and it was amazing. Hubby had the flat iron steak and he enjoyed it very much, I had the New York strip special and it was delicious. I had asked Nicolette to request a very fatty cut and it was just what I was needing (I am doing pseudo keto diet and had a marathon to run the next day). My steak came with loaded mashed potatoes (hubby enjoyed those), green beans, and some sort of squash, I asked for extra butter for the green beans and everything was delicious.  Hubby had the pineapple upside down for dessert, it came with pineapple gelato, I had a microscopic sample of each and it was good, the gelato was very tasty without being overly sweet. Over all a very good experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pineapple upside down with gelato
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Flat iron steak
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. New York Strip special

PdxTu_LqdnwDPMn_AYzeiA.text: We ate here for a big team dinner this week. There were twelve of us and we sat outside on the patio which is delightful. It was a chilly evening, but they moved all kinds of heaters around our table to make everyone comfortable.   First up....It's hard to find the door! Our Uber driver dropped us off at the address and we were like...where is it?? You have to walk up the large cement stairs and then you'll see the cool neon blue dog sign. Inside - it's gorgeous! COOOOOL bar area with these neat hanging lights. Great place for a date!! LOVE the vibe.   The drinks are awesome! I tried the Hibiscus Belle Fleur drink and it came with a beautiful flower in the glass. So fun, and so tasty. Kind of sweet, but not overly so. Everyone at the table loved their cocktails. It seems like they are all worth trying.   We shared almost every single appetizer so we could try different things. Everyone freaked out about the deviled eggs! They have bacon jam at the bottom. Wowza. My favorite two appetizers were the flatbread and the sunchokes. But everything was great. I think it would be fine to just have a bunch of apps for dinner - they are that good.   Someone in my party was craving the hamburger from the website photo... Turned out they ran out at lunch time! So no burgers at dinner.   I had the roasted chicken as my entree. I received two chicken pieces, still on the bone. Very juicy and well seasoned. There was a lot of quinoa on my plate. i was wishing there was more butternut puree or more veggies. It was a good meal.   I recommend this place for sure. Good for groups and also good for dates. It's not a place for kids - very adult vibe. I would come back if I'm in Phoenix visiting again.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States

D5_jdPuT-aZml_SFjnOy2Q.text: Came here before a concert for some appetizers. Horrible food and we didn't eat any of it. We got wings and mac and cheese. The mac and cheese tasted like milk and had cheetos on top of it. The wings were dry.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shishito peppers

CqMNzSnW04cktak65dOpNg.text: Diverse menu with local specialties as well as quality standbys (steaks!) and craft cocktail menu. Service was excellent.

G3B1JWc1-jggZ7jBEDd9gg.text: Classy place. Great section of liquor, beer and wine. Bartenders are highly skilled and can probably make anything you ask for. Prices aren't cheap though. Expect to pay around $15 for anything specialty. Half that for anything "normal" like a vodka tonic. They do have a happy hour menu though if you want to save a few bucks.

V3xiPvtJg73_ao8y3_qN-Q.text: I am always up for a great cocktail and a classy atmosphere, and blue hound has both! Their list of cocktails is extensive and the knowledge of their staff is substantial as well. The only issue I ran into was price. Now for drinks only it's fairly reasonable considering the area and skill of the staff, but the food seemed a little pricey. The food was delicious just a little expensive for portion size.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shared cheese board- $22
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The Lion King cocktail- absolutely delicious

wu8d1HMp6ne0RhtTvs1Abg.text: Fun little Christmas pop up, luckily wasn't too crowded because it's a pretty small space. The run run Rudolph cocktail was tasty, refreshing. Snowball old fashion good if you love butterscotch.

kD0tEgxW9gkHB8acIxOgbQ.text: We showed up after a late arrival at the airport and getting our rental car. We were not dressed as nicely as we should have been for this place but the staff was friendly and very accommodating. The restaurant is lovely with great ambiance. We had their craft cocktails and we all enjoyed them. We had chicken bite and seared tuna appetizers. Both were delicious. Kids enjoyed both. Our waiter did an amazing job making chocolate milk for our boys...I mean seriously delicious! I had the pasta which was good. My husband has the shrimp and grits and let me say, those grits were incredibly flavorful and smooth. Our friends got the buratta salad and pork shank. I was told it was the best pork shank he had had before. The buratta salad was very good with great crusty bread...my friend wish it had more tomatoes. Our kids got pasta that ended up costing same as an adult even though it was butter and Parmesan cheese...they didn't that option on the kids menu. We kept watching the desserts go by and they looked amazing but we didn't get one because we were full. It was a pricey dinner but very good and enjoyed it all!

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Delicious martini...can&#39;t remember the name but it was very good!
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Blue hound in the bar...too cute!

dLgPtBFH9LYqmqKU0NfGFw.text: My family and I were in town for the Cactus Bowl.  This was within walking distance of our hotel and also it was open on Christmas day.  Made reservations.  This is a pretty nice hotel located downtown near all the sports venues.  The menu had a variety of options.  I ordered the fried catfish with shrimp. It was delicious!  My son had the roasted chicken.  His was very moist and tasty.  My catfish was cooked perfectly and the shrimp and sauce was absolutely amazing!  I would definitely recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Roasted chicken
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Fried catfish with shrimp

CCIwI1eqiUZ30hjYGuDSKw.text: Legit amazing. If you don't get the chopped salad you messed up. Also got the pasta and it was amazing too. Christopher was a great server everything was 10/10

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Vegan pasta
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chopped Salad

7iZ2U-ja_l9O-5aBMVv1qg.text: The most terrible service I've ever experienced. Made a reservation for the patio. Seated by hostess and it was 15 mins & not one person came outside, let alone our table. I went inside to let the hostess know that no one had come to our table at all and she was busy busing a table. She said she would let someone know right away. A guy showed up with water to tell us our server was busy. After another 10 mins sitting there and hadn't ordered anything we decided to leave. Bad experience, period!

2MYqb6wGT1CJ0-8dRobBEA.text: So I hate to write a somewhat negative review, BUT, maybe it was an off night.  Or maybe the last time my husband and daughter went, it was exceptional then. They brought me back, our third time to the restaurant, to try the Ricotta Gnudi.  They loved it so much they wanted me to try to duplicate it at home.  But since we were in town, I figured I would try it.  The time before it was evidently filled with mushrooms.  Brimming with srooms so much that the dish was filling then.  This time, not one mushroom.  And it was the serving size of a ladle.  Which one do s accurate?!?  But both my husband and daughter said it was disappointing.  The Brussel Sprouts were great tho.  The next disappointment worth mentioning was that my husband ordered the Salmon as he usually does at any restaurant.  They brought out the Lamb Osco Brusco (?) can't remember exact name. He didn't want to complain, so he ate it, but I can tell he was disappointed.  The third major disappointment was my 11 yr old ordered the Sirloin.  We had asked about a pasta for her, but not the carbonara.  So she ordered the steak and we asked if she could get fries with it instead of another side.  She said it doesn't come with a side, but we could order the family style sides.  She suggested the potatoes which my 11 yr old wouldn't touch.  What was incredibly disappointing is that she brought out steak fries for my 19 yr old with her steak.  Talk about a disappointing experiences. We also ordered the family style mushrooms, and they were burnt on the ends, but also cold to eat.  Disappointing experience and good when they were clearly not busy on a Sunday evening.

ihiDmTS_GTGWvCpgKQRvXg.text: Ate at Blue Hound tonight with some co- workers. Overall, all 7 of us were disappointed. First off let me say that the hostess and the bar back were kind. Besides those two- everyone else seem to be extremely unhappy to be working. The bartender with the long beard and the ponytail was extremely unfriendly. It is not that hard to smile and be nice to your guests. He was shaking his head it was obvious that he was poff at something. I ordered my $35 steak medium and it came well done. My coworker did not receive her food until after we had all finished ours. She had been watching it sit on the ready up in the kitchen while we all ate. They offered to make her a new one.A woman came over and took it off her bill but the lack of apology for her not receiving her food was shocking. Honestly that's not what we were looking for, we wanted to see that they were apologetic for the slow service. I understand the concept of ordering at the bar. But to charge high end prices the concept doesn't blend. If I'm paying $65 for one drink (one shot of whiskey) a steak and some brussels sprouts somebody better be checking up on my food and ensuring that my meal was prepared well. I couldn't even express that my steak was over done because nobody gave me the opportunity to. I normally don't get bad reviews I'm an advocate for supporting, but they have seven out of town or's walk out of your restaurant extremely disappointed with the lack of service and quality of food for the prices we paid needed to be shared with management. Since we did not have a server I was forced to leave this review.

j7ed-0TPcEV5TY7bK3MKuA.text: Sitting in the bar waiting for dinner to arrive.  I am posting a review early because I was just served one of their seasonal cocktails, the Mulled Over, and it has to be one of the best craft cocktails I have ever had. Well done Blue Hound!

ImuI1qLuEH8EP5jhN8ObIA.text: Always love coming here.  Good food,  great drinks,  great staff.   Love the central location,  especially when there are no events so the place is a little quieter.  Had a friend in from Chicago who loved the place.  It was the first stop on our circuit for the evening.

k-q1-5kW0WBNJiTIWmSrng.text: Food is good - the paperdelle with sausage ragu was GREAT.  Drinks were inventive, modern, cool.  Bartenders were great - fast, friendly, helpful, but could stand a bit more training.  I overheard one describe Aperol as being cherry flavored, and another, when describing a whiskey I was unfamiliar with told me that it was named based on the type of grain in it.  That seemed odd, so I looked it up and found out it was the name of the still used, not a grain.  I realize these things aren't the end of the world, and we're in Phoenix, not New York or San Francisco, but as a former service industry peon and eventual manager who stupidly described something she did not understand and has never forgotten the shame, I'm always in favor of better training. The space is cozy and welcoming - definitely worth checking out. And if you want to really wow a date this winter, take them ice skating and then pop in here for the o.g. lawless.  Third date material shiz right there.

UQAaIkflDxbySrrSoxYCSA.text: Phil was excellent the female bartender however was the worst bartender I have had in years. She was so unfriendly by our entire party that we may never be back. She did however make good drinks. So give or take I guess. She would have had a way better tip with nicer service.  We did not have food so can not comment on that.

aiDpEq9jDM_LGO76XPUq4Q.text: I arrived at around 7 PM on a Saturday night and asked for a table for three. I was told by two nice hostesses that their tables were all reserved and booked until 8:15 ish, but that I could take my drinks and food to a seating area in the adjoining hotel. I just wanted to grab some light nosh and my friends who were meeting me were driving from the airport, straight off of a flight, and we had a concert to catch, so I decided to grab a seat at the bar instead.   I expected it to be difficult to find a seat at the bar but surprisingly, there was one open and available. I didn't have to wait for more than a few seconds before a menu was placed in front of me and a quick second later that I was given an extensive liquor list.  Service was prompt and expeditious and the bartenders were knowledgable and kind. I ordered the short rib sliders and shishito peppers, wanting to grab something that could be made quickly and that the bartender said the kitchen could whip up within minutes. And the appetizers were brought up from the kitchen within five or so minutes of ordering! I was shocked because of how quickly they were ready but the server reassured me that the dishes were fresh.  And the sliders were divine - perfect five bites of tender and large hunks of meat sandwiched between plump rolls. The horseradish sauce that was on the short rib wasn't overpowering, was piquant and nicely complimented the short rib.   The shishito peppers were delicious! Not too greasy (like other shishito peppers I've had) and was accompanied by a creamy Siracha dipping sauce and that was such a nice flavor thaf complimented the peppers but didn't take away from the flavor of the peppers.   I also had a delicious glass of their Laphroaig scotch and asked for it with a smidgen of water. I was served a small carafe of water to splash on top of the scotch. And it was divine! Their liquor menu is impressive and extensive - they carry a large selection of scotches from all over the world and whiskeys, both domestic and even the coveted Japanese whiskeys.   I will definitely be returning and next time, bringing my husband for a date. I can't wait to peruse their dinner menu and to try their selection of interesting dishes.

MNRFLM_TqGiVPzGgJikiCQ.text: Cocktails were great. Service was fantastic. Attentive but not bothersome. Appetizers were exceptional.   For cocktails we started with and old fashioned and the margarita tropical. Both were exceptional.   We ordered appetizers. The flat bread and the pork belly sliders. Both were outstanding. I highly recommend the sliders. I wouldn't come back here without ordering them.   We passed on ordering an entree because they were a little pricey. Probably the only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars.   The atmosphere is great for a date night or a night out.   If you like a strong original whiskey drink, get the lawless.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Old fashioned and tropical margarita

jLCmy7x9bAjbutOeDTvucQ.text: Would so have given 5 stars if it wasn't hot as hell in here. We love Jesse, Jake, and Patrick, they have made making drinks an art and we love them all. Literally the best mixologists around. The drinks are delicious just tell them what you base liquor is and they will create magic every time.

LZHzzT0Qsnf-CtgXmfVMrg.text: This is a really neat spot, despite it being in a hotel. The bar and restaurant area are upscale and the Manhattans will make you slap ya mama! We had the BLT with fried green tomatoes....the way to go...and their 4 cheese Flatbread (on special) was on point! Very crispy and thin...loved it. The martinis were a bit small, but packed a punch. Prohibition era drinks was a nice concept.   This is a good place to go when there is an event. It won't be as crowded as the other places that are easier to find...

1YfTumi4bZv7EFb0dJd3bg.text: I came here for a business dinner meeting. Overall I was very impressed. The interior decor was modern classic flair with a rustic feel to it just to start. It has several options for space of you wanted to talk as a group privately or at an open table.  We had several options that I posted pictures of but the stand outs were fried oysters and ahi tuna for staters. For entrees the Cajun style craw fish and rice the best dish around followed by the pork shank on a bed of risotto.  We had the compliment of two bottles of wine that was stellar, Justin obviously a favorite from our central coast of CA followed by the Malbec which was the stellar on their selection as well. The best part of why this place deserves 5 stars is their service and price point . Most stellar entrees are in the low to mid 20s and top shelf wine in the 60s . Such great value even though we didn't pay for dinner . Top notch and my kind of place for a professional meal in a more laid back setting

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Catfish with Cajun style crawfish on a bed of rice
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork shank on a bed of risotto
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States

pM6dS_UBqIttlvUayz9MJA.text: The Blue Hound at CityScape in downtown Phoenix is a delightfully hip addition to the burgeoning Phoenix downtown dining scene. It features a reasonably priced New American (tilted toward Southern) menu, with a selection of great entrees and an outstanding cocktail list.  There is a very cool bar, that is right off the adjoining Hotel Palomar.  We split a delicious chopped salad, that reminded us a lot of the chopped salad at Citizen Public House in Scottsdale.  Not sure if there is an ownership overlap or a bit of plagiarism, but in any case, it was yummy.  My wife had the shrimp and grits and I had the swordfish entree.  Both were prepared well and and delivered promptly by our server.  Once again, both high on the yummy scale!  For dessert we shared the cherry pie, which was every bit as tasty as a pie purchased at the legendary Rock Springs Cafe in Black Canyon City, and a lot closer to home, for most of us.  Parking in the garage next door was validated, making this a destination well worth the drive from the suburbs.  We certainly will be back!

JIDyxqyB0MGtuyXVZ0pEeA.text: Came here with a date last night, it was my first dinning experience downtown on a friday night, and Blue Hound definitely lived up to its reputation.  We sat in the outside patio, and it was nice and cool out and more private than the main floor.   This place has a hip vibe, and was nicely packed at the time, the food menu was way different than I expected, but most of the items we ordered were SMASHING.  -Ribs fell off the bone, and tasted rich and actually mixed pretty damn well with blue cheese grits..who woulda thought that?   -Corn on the Cob, (mexican street style as my waiter said) were my favorite though, you gotta try this one time, the taste is explosive lol...   -Tater Tots- bomb-tastic, better than I've had in a minute, which is saying a lot. ha  Service was strange, but attentive. Not all in your face, which could be a good thing or bad thing for some people. Our waiter was chill though.   drinks wre str8, but not strong which was probably a good thing in my case, lol.   Would love to support a local business like this more on the regular, and recommend it to everyone.  4 STARS.

4uRrC0ZyH3ryOLWoXQ462A.text: I've tried this place 2x now and am a BH groupie,  I think. I'd highly recommend waiting for a coveted patio seating - excellent cityscape views and close enough to people watch (one of my hobbies).  Brunch here is truly divine - especially if it's a nice, blue-sky day. I had the egg frittata and Mimosa. Dinner is great also. Very relaxed and ideal place for date, friends or chill "unwind" place w/coworker(s)!   Try the ceviche tacos - I think you'll be pleasantly surprised. The Tots (Tater) are scrumptious also.  Also LOVE the fact that they have ability to make the Nat'l drink of Peru - the Pisco Sour.   My colleague and I were treated like royalty here - customer service blew me away. We had 2 separate servers (one for meal and other for drinks, etc), and they were so friendly and helpful. They both did frequent check-ins without being pesky flies. Unfortunately, I didn't catch their names. Our female server never batted an eye when I requested "a side of olive brine for my STRONG dirty martini". Made me feel nice inside. :)  Great job, Hound!

xx2t3_VpSA03aS0E85_uQw.text: Very fancy schmancy for a happy hour- but it IS a hotel restaurant in downtown Phoenix... It comes with an impressive cocktail menu. The old fashioned with peach bitters is on freaking point. A great date night spot if your looking to shmoooze her. Also, their fried green tomatoes with lump crab appetizer is amazing. This place take craft cocktails and quality food to the next level.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cocktail menu

lWFaJLs0kCQiqFBwqG5FKQ.text: Came here for restaurant week and it's hard to get to with construction going on and all the one way streets.  You really have to know downtown Phx to get to the valet or public parking.    Once we got to the Palomar Hotel to the 2nd floor to the Blue Hound Kitchen it was very nice.  The ambience really has a cool vibe and a very urban feeling.  I checked out the website and the pictures do not do it justice.    We had drinks at the side bar and the waitress was very attentive to the point we had to tell her we are meeting another couple, we are going to chat THEN we will sit down at our table.  Granted it was restaurant week but it wasn't as busy as we thought it would be.  Anyhow, we finally sit and peruse the menu.  It looked amazing so we decide instead of ordering the set restaurant week menu we would order the appetizers and try them out.  They were intriguing to us.  We order a fabulous bottle of Petite Syrah for only $40 bucks.....  2 hours later we tried pretty much tried all the appetizers and they were delicious.  Great flavors, the corn appetizer you have to cut yourself off the cob.  Corn cutting of the cob skills needed!  It was fun and filling.  We did manage to order the beef short ribs and 3 out 4 thought they were fabulous.  Our 4th person thought it had way too much fat for what you are paying...30+.  He did think the flavor and taste was great!   Our waiter was pretty good.  He was attentive for certain things but we sat with empty and near empty water glasses for awhile. All in all it was a great experience...little things like the bar waitress being too attentive I guess makes up for our waiter not being as attentive with certain things.  Would I go here again?  Yes!

AfeY_I09kAWquptHaOQDGA.text: Wonderful selection of mixed drinks and cocktails. I would try something new if I were you, they've done everything right.  Tonight we shared appetizers and enjoyed them all.

fW6hIBdijUsfoQ1oCWifeA.text: Great location in downtown Phoenix! We had a kind server and lovely seats with interesting view, as we were surrounded by sky scrapers. Our dishes were tasty, though I found there to be some downsides...the ribs we ordered as an appetizer were flavorful, though someone in the kitchen went heavy on the salt. We also had these fried meat balls with rice inside, atop a thick tomato sauce--this was possibly the best dish of the evening. For my entree, I ordered the Papardelle, which was good. Still, parpadelle noodles are to be wide, but, these were straight up lasagna noodles (????). My boyfriend ordered a steak and thoroughly enjoyed it, except for the potatoes which felt undercooked to him and bland. Some real hits here, but also needs some improvement

CZNGRjMmCVzFw-oXgAlnmw.text: Came here with my wife for lunch. Visiting AZ from Portland, OR. Wife and I consider ourselves junior foodies - we really enjoyed this place. Great decor, feels very open inside. The food was good. Po'Boy was nice, wife enjoyed her burger very much. She also commented positively on her salad; fun to see watermelon radishes in it. The fries were garlic-y in the best way and seasoned generously with Rosemary. Yum. Nice to see Deschutes on tap, reminds me of home. Recommended.

Ld7lguT2IMy1ailMrZ73fA.text: Definitely one of my favorite spots in downtown!! Awesome cocktails, friendly waitstaff and some of the most experienced and well versed bartenders I have ever had.   The pork belly sliders, the seemingly traditional downtown PHX shishito peppers and the casual atmosphere make BHK one of the best jump offs for a night in the central corridor. Perfect start, or end, to every night.. Definitely gets packed during the peak dinner hours tho! So go prepared!!

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cauliflower croquettes, pork belly sliders, sharishito peppers and deviled eggs. The start for our night of apps on the town!

G5Nl5A2_X6-jYqxJpqLAkQ.text: Almost want to hold back a star because of how impossible it was to have a conversation at the bar but the food was so good that I'm giving it up! Plus they were so nice about getting us a table even though we didn't have reservations. We had just planned for the team to meet up for drinks for a super casual work meeting, but it was too loud. Hey, it's a busy bar, it happens.  I just wish places like this would invest in the sound cancelling tech that I read about in Wired mag. Not dead quiet, just dialed down a bit.   OK, the food, amazing boudin balls, fried green maters and shrimp grits that rivaled the stuff I had on my last trip in the deep south.   It really seems to me that regional food is being done better outside its home turf. I noticed that in the Bay Area as well. I visit NYC for work frequently but have yet to find a better pastrami sandwich there, than the one (maybe seven), I had in San Carlos.   Very good cocktail menu here also. Love the creativity and balance. I had to stop at three because I hate to fly with a hangover but next time, Ill try more on the list.

iDPFV_hJdMV2LFXSCvfX3Q.text: After a so-so experience at a steakhouse the day before, I had higher hopes for this place. Once again I was with a group eating on someone else's dime, so price was no concern except as a way to judge value.   It's nestled in a corner of a high-rise surrounded by other anonymous corporate quarters. It aspires to be more than a place for suits to get lunch, however. The menu has signature cocktails, small plates and offbeat entrees that call out to foodies and hipsters, "You're special, and we know it."  We had small plate/appetizers for the table, including roasted shishito peppers, cheese plate, deviled eggs and tater tots. I really liked the peppers and eggs, which had fried yolks as well as the usual whipped yolks. Cheese plate was a nice selection of good quality cheeses. Tots were just okay.  My entree was a braised beef short rib on grits. The presentation was a knockout, with a Flintstones size rib poking over the edge of the bowl with the grits at the bottom. Rib was evidently roasted to finish, giving it a little char flavor, and the texture was still a little toothy, not fall off the bone tender, which is better for a short rib I think.  Service was good but cool, as you should expect in a place like this. Overall a good experience, but I give it three rather than four stars because I think the prices are not in line with the cuisine. Maybe being in downtown means high rent, which forces them to charge like this, but I wouldn't pay those prices if it were my money.

VcsMaDlnaQ6ELrYK5KIrxg.text: Good spot downtown.  Great decor, if you really like the restoration hardware look.  Service was sort of meh....we had the pork belly sliders for a starter-they were good but I didn't think they were the greatest.  I had the tucson chow da, it was good...but honestly it was mussels clams and two shrimp in a cream and pepper broth, the little fingerlings were good but seemed like an afterthought.    The drinks were good here, very good.  The Romeo and violette was different, could easily drink those by the pint.  Margaritas were some of the best around.     Suffered from mediocre service and an honestly not too memorable dining.  Good...but I don't think I'd go back for dinner.  Definitely would hit this place up for a drink or three.

GKGQPJGkglkVUU2UFKHuNQ.text: Love this place, the service is excellent and the drinks are to die for. Robert is the best bartender of the bunch. He has great suggestions for drinks if you're not sure and makes a mean rum old fashion.  I never miss a chance to come here when I'm downtown.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Rum Old Fashion, yum!

c4BArPl2_ASbIUdhu8Xnig.text: Enjoyed my meal and cocktail here.  The manhattan was delicious!  Perfect blend of rye, bitters and peel. Salmon seasoning was delicate yet robust on a perfectly cooked fillet.   I look forward to returning here.

xN8SQQSko8wfQDTBLNK88g.text: We were refused by the hostess with over half of the tables and booths being empty. The gal was good at being argumental however her arguments were not powered by intelligence. After persuasion we we're finally sat at a table near the bar that had been marked "reserved" along with three others in the row. We proceeded to order cocktails that we're delicious and then a light dinner which was also quite flavorful. The rest of the staff was very friendly and accommodating as a service industry professional should be. We sat in the booth for 40 minutes and had a $78 tab. Upon departure the booth next to us was still empty and the one on the other side was empty about half way through our visit and remained so till we departed. I am unsure the logic still to this moment she was instilling but I must say we chose after being soured by her lack of service to venture caddy corner to Bitter and Twisted where the hostess was lovely as well as welcoming! Maybe she should train the hostesses over at the Blue Hound! The bartenders were skilled, the waitress was perfect and the food was good and hot! I feel the experience was very dulled by it's initial interaction that one star is where I could rate, but that would not be fair to the rest of the establishments personnel that did do a great job!

qtwXSYDgTHZ3HiauvauXsA.text: Took us 15 minutes to get a beer with only 5-10 other customers in the entire place (who were already served). Won't go back. For the $9/beer price it should be much better than that!

kIztlnAq7LVhQOb7_q21Nw.text: Stopped here for a late lunch. Hostess proceeded to make a reservation confirmation call before addressing us, as in we were standing in front of her and she picked up the phone and dialed, not already on the phone. Really cool interior, and i really enjoyed my Duck and Cover cocktail. Food was just okay and served with a free side of pretension. Mac n cheese was very bland - needed an acidic element.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States

FprDlIeSxCs12lt75DIMqQ.text: This past summer I took my fiance to the Blue Hound for his going away dinner. I made my reservation online and simply noted that he was heading to Afghanistan and asked for a table with a nice view.   We arrived and were taken to a table with a fabulous view! I was thoroughly satisfied, but had no idea what was to come. We ordered the Chef's Geek Out and were absolutely blown away by the service, food and accompanying drinks. Little did we know that at the end of our meal the Chef and staff would bring a card to the table, shake his hand and express their sincere appreciation and ask that we please come back when he returns.   I can't recommend Blue Hound enough and we will gladly return when he gets back!

xGanaxECJzuYp4PtRxCBdg.text: I can't say enough about the ingenious cocktails they craft at Blue Hound. They are some of the most delicious and inventive drinks I've ever tasted. A must for any night out downtown.

RRzdkijTL2OVeAZNzOSFFw.text: WARNING their drink menu has changed!!! If you like playing cocktail roulette or If you like picking your craft cocktails from a picture book, this is your new place! The new cocktail menu is ludacris! It has nice pictures of cocktails with numbers that lead you to a blurb that gives no description on what the drink is besides what city it was created in and by who. This sadly leaves you having a 20 minute discussion with your waiter/waitress on why and how this menu works and sadly enough they don't have all 40 some cocktails memorized so you get some diluted version of the ingredients with a lot of "ummms" and "wellsssss". Like most, I would assume we like to have some knowledge of what we are drinking rather than "oh that looks nice in a picture and we call it Lion King and it's from Phoenix, created by a guy named Jake...I'm sure he's a great guy...." I would assume that most of us go out looking to enjoy a nice cocktail and chat with our company not the wait staff who is  trying to depict a menu. This used to be our go to place for nice cocktails and food... It was also our go to place for our out of town guests. It is always the first place we have in mind to go. Blue hound has amazing food and cocktails. They just seem to be a little confused right now. Not sure if I will be going back until the cocktails are back in order. This is business suicide and Also!... Bring back the "lawless"! How do you take the best drink off a menu? Sad...

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Th5gjaK5Efo8ohaOR_QP6A.text: This place is a gem of a hotel lobby bar. I'm sure they hate being referred to as a lobby bar, but it is what it is. It's owned and operated by Kimpton, but with the atmosphere and offerings comparable to other successful gastro-lounges in the  Phoenix area, I think this place would also do well if it were a stand-alone operation. Come for a cocktail, or two, grab some 'gastropub tapas', and wash them down with another cocktail, or two.   Service at the bar can take longer than you'd like, but understandably so. The mixologists aren't just shelling out drinks, but rather, handcrafting cocktails that fire on all cylinders--presentation, taste, and price. I love the bourbon-heavy menu, with the Lawless and Old Belle being my go-to cocktails. Yea, they're up there in price, but Old Fashioneds are $6 on the HH menu Mon-Fri.  As stated in most reviews, the Kimchi Pork Belly Sliders are pretty bomb! Most of their bar menu items can be ordered in different sizes as to promote sharing and sampling of more menu items, a definite plus.   Unfortunately, I think the bartender told me the kitchen was closed when I was there on Sunday. I think I hit the lull between lunch and dinner service(3-5pm). It was definitely a bummer. Of course I don't know what your numbers look like, but I hope you have all the variables factored into your equations. I would've stayed and ordered another drink if I had food to go along with it. One drink alone would've covered an hour worth of kitchen labor. You should consider posting a sign that says,  "We apologize to our patrons Sat-Sun 3-5pm, but our dreadful attempts at saving four hours of labor per week result in a disservice to our customers. We'd rather you eat and drink elsewhere."  All in all, 5 stars for the drinks and food (when I can get it). 1 star deducted for teasing me with a cocktail, and not pleasing me with food.

photos.caption: Photo of Blue Hound - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Old Belle with a single square cube

ij9DdyO66HxTFVM7sWZRfw.text: This was my second time to Blue Hound - and I am a fan.  First things first - it's a bit hard to find due to it being in the Palomar hotel. Just go to the Lobby of the Palomar (which isn't at street level FYI) and turn right. Voila. You are there.   This was the first time I have been here for dinner, the other was for lunch. So I waited for my friend at the bar. So, for it being a pretty small bar - and I was sitting at it - it took a long time for a bar tender to come and ask what I wanted. In fact, it wasn't until my friend got there that they even asked. I would rate the bar service not so great. Another instance of trying to do side work, and not paying attention to who is at the bar. And, then we ordered two simple drinks - a glass of chardonnay and a tanqueray rocks, and that even took some serious time to get.  For starters - I would definitely recommend them. Deviled eggs are awesome, although fundamentally a little odd to get at a restaurant and not a backyard bbq. Fried green tomatoes are delish and definitely try the short rib sliders. My only issue with the short rib sliders is I am not such a fan of the sweet rolls, but the meat is awesome.  For dinner, I think I am a little hung up here. I can't say I loved the stuffed chicken. (Does not appear to be on the menu anymore.) Turned out a bit dry for me. But the accompaniments were great - cauliflower, veggies, etc.   Overall, it's a neat place. I like the setting, I am just not sure of the food. Appears to be a southern twist - so I am thrown off by the trout, shrimp, etc., as they just aren't my thing. But I think it's a good place to go for a drink and some apps.

hdAW1p_LE4nfk7aPkEhGyw.text: I made a reso on opentable for a father's day get together for 7. When I found out an 8th would be joining, called the restaurant and my call was answered promptly and I was informed that it would be no problem at all to add another person to the party.  The food was great. Deviled eggs were delicious, salmon + shrimp was great, salmon cooked medium-ish so it was super moist, chopped salad was good (but not as good as The Gladly's) and the drinks were fun and experiential (one came with tobacco smoke)  Daniel Jimenez was our server and he was outstanding. Great with recos, very friendly, and took photos of our group per our request, even though he had a busy section.  Only downfall may be the prices as they seem somewhat high vs similar restaurants.  All in all a great night with great food and seamless, outstanding service.

C4rty6r3nyZ2OH-_dO29Yg.text: Tonight was our third time eating here. Food is amazing. Everything on the menu is superb and unique. Service is always great. Highly recommend. Only suggestion is blue cheese olives for Martinis.

GnyJWvAV4EPFhSuoPL_qNQ.text: I ordered a cocktail (Special K), an appetizer (deviled eggs), and an entree (shrimp and grits).  The cocktail was fantastic!  The deviled eggs were good... I noticed they tasted a bit salty when taking multiple bites, but the balance is perfect if you eat them in one bite.  I was a little disappointed in the shrimp and grits, just because it was so rich.  It smelled overwhelmingly of butter.  I mean, it was delicious, but too heavy.  The service was great too.

rvTHZV3NJqtOV-DKbx2ZZg.text: This place has great ambience and great food. The chef has done a really nice job combining flavors. Their cocktails at the bar are also skillfully blended. 4lS6O0UQXAyG0EyJk7H-ag.text: Its a restaurant that's still very much in its infancy and still has some kinks to work out, but so far this new downtown spot is off to a pretty good start.  My siblings and I took my Dad here for Father's Day.  Surprisingly, it was packed (not with Father's Day peeps but rather a ton of folks in town for various conventions).  The restaurant matches well with the feel of the Hotel Palomar in general.  Modern and eclectic.  As for the food?  They strongly encourage sharing dishes amongst the whole table so they offer have and full portions of all their dishes.  For vegetarians, they have a farm fresh menu of various veggie combo dishes.  For the appetizer, we got a full order of tater tots (yes, tater tots).  Decent flavor, a little oily.  For the main dish my Dad and I both got the short rib (which is huge by the way), while my bro got the fried quail, and my sis got the gizpacho.  The short rib was juicy, fall off the bone tender with a perfect char.  My brother's quail was pretty good, but we unfortunately discovered some bones still embedded in the quail.  Not sure if it was supposed to be that way, but it was an unpleasant surprise from an otherwise tasty dish.  My sister said the gizpacho was so-so.  Overall, the food was good but not great as some dishes probably still need some work.  The atmosphere of the place and the friendly wait staff made up for some of this place's shortcomings and they even comped the appetizer for sitting us in a noisy area with the convention goers.  They didn't have to do that, but it was a nice gesture.  As a whole, I would absolutely bring my friends here for happy hour as they have a really cool bar area with a decent cocktail selection and the modern look of the place is a great conversation piece.  As far as the restaurant itself, I think it has potential.  Its only been open two weeks and I know every new place goes through some growing pains, so I'm willing to give them a pass on some of menu misfires for now.  Hopefully next time I come by they'll have worked out the kinks and lived up to their potential.

8k7cBjF7YL-RKwpYQn2GuA.text: Holiday Rip-off at Blue Hound: most pathetic holiday buffet ever. My husband and I were looking for a Christmas Day restaurant option, as it was going to be just the two of us (why cook?) but it's also his birthday. Yup, Xmas baby. So when I saw that Blue Hound had a Christmas breakfast buffet, I was excited, as the place has been on my "must try" list since we moved to PHX a couple of years ago. What a disappointment. Bigly.  Now, $36 for a holiday buffet isn't bad at all, and as it was a breakfast/brunch offering, we didn't expect the moon. When we walked in and saw the meager layout, I wanted to leave, but my husband was hungry, and there are not many options on Christmas. I figured, the food will be really good, per their rep, so we'll stay.  The scrambled eggs were like a yellow sponge from sitting over the heat. No seasonings, no add-ins, just plain ol' eggs. Next up, the breakfast sausage links were cold and gray; they didn't even bother to grill them. Nuked or steamed, they were unappetizing to say the least. Now, the applewood bacon was quite good; I ended up chowing a lot of it because I was starving - hadn't eaten anything that morning - and everything else was so lame. The third treat was shriveled, plain potato wedges. Again, no discernible seasonings, and apparently no one in the kitchen could find any onions, bell peppers or mushrooms - anything - to jazz them up a bit. And barely lukewarm.  No waffles, no pancakes. Every crummy hotel chain has a Belgian waffle maker, but even that was too much to hope for here.  The tray of pastries looked pretty sad, but I was desperate. Yuck. The Danish were stone-cold, wet and heavy. The bear claws, dry and heavy. Supposedly there had been muffins at some point, the waitress said. The bagels were standard supermarket issue, i.e., basically donut-shaped bread. Oh joy, they had some smoked salmon. How festive.  The big finale were parfaits, about 1/3 cup each, with sour, out-of-season berries and a fruit tray dominated by melons and strawberries: they look great, but are tasteless this time of year. Finished up with watery coffee.   At least our waitress was good. Still, I was even more irked to see that a 20% gratuity was tacked on the bill. For a party of two. Really?  Grand total for all this holiday cheer: $92.52. My husband didn't want to complain, so I let it go while we were there, but on Monday, I was still annoyed that they'd wrecked our holiday/birthday brunch. I left a message for the manager on the restaurant voicemail, and of course, silence.  No response IS a response. Like the buffet, it means "fa la la la la you."

9yRVC2TbJkX9pSs8eMsf9w.text: It's always a treat to visit Blue Hound Kitchen & Cocktails, whether you're feasting on innovative creations by Chef Stephen Jones, who pours love into every dish, or sipping on one of the delicious handcrafted cocktails for happy hour. I was invited to try some of the newest offerings on Jones' current spring/summer menu, made with organic and locally sourced ingredients that perfectly complement each other for a symphony in your mouth.  This meal (thank you to J. Lauren PR for the invitation), my pal Elle and I grabbed a seat outside on the patio, overlooking CityScape in downtown Phoenix.  Not only was the weather perfect, we could hear tunes from neighboring Copper Blues. Like Elle pointed out, the music was great because it provided great background melodies that allowed us to still hear what each other was saying.  Like all my visits at Blue Hound, the service, from the hostess to every single server who visited our table (including the knowledgeable and friendly Justis), was top-notch. Kudos to Blue Hound for properly training their staff in menu proficiency and professionalism.  We started with two delicious drinks - the Singapore Sling ($10) was made with Arizona Distilling Co. gin, Benedictine, pineapple juice, lemon juice, and Cherry Heering liqueur. Justis told us the drink is modeled after original Tiki drinks, and we both agreed the balance of sweet and sour was great  I also got the Lost Melody ($10), a frothy concoction with Smirnoff vodka, grapefruit liquer, coconut cream, grapefruit juice, and rose flower water. It tasted like dessert in a drink, which was totally fine with me, and I loved inhaling the coconut scents with every tasty sip.  My pal and I split a ton of plates, perfectly portioned for sharing, during our feast. First up was the Cured Strawberry and Fennel Flatbread ($14), with pickeled fennel (a favorite ingredient of Chef Jones - read my Phoenix People interview with him here), pistachio, wild baby arugula and ricotta cheese. I've never had strawberries on a pizza, but let me tell you, the flatbread was delicious and tasted just like what you'd think of when it comes to spring.  We also dug into the Avocado salad ($9), with blood oranges, grapefruit and wild greens. Elle described it perfectly as "chic diet food,'" a light and fresh salad you could feel good eating right before a night out or before getting into a swimsuit, since it was healthy and light. I loved the fruit and avocado combination and gobbled up every bite.  Elle loved the Tater Tots she ordered (a small portion at $7), which had bacon and chive made right in the tots. "These are every college kid's wet dream," she said, noting the bacon baked in was a spectacular touch.  We both enjoyed the Corn Bread Panzanella ($9), a bread salad with artichoke, fava beans, baby leeks, and peas mixed with an herb vinaigrette. It was really filing and would be a great appetizer to share.  Surprisingly, maybe our favorite savory dish was the Roasted Cauliflower ($9), really simple but oh-so-good because, like most of Blue Hound's offerings, it combined sweet, savory and salty to satisfy all your palate's tastes. It came with pistachios, capers and currants, and Justis said it's simply cooked by poaching the cruciferous vegetable in milk before charring it a little in a skillet, then adding in the capers, currants and a touch of butter and herbs.  Elle summed up the meal perfectly: "I would never have thought of putting this stuff together, but it's exactly what I want," she said.  I was full, but we asked Justis to surprise us with dessert. He brought out the latest dessert menu item, the BHPB&J ($9), a twist on PB&J with whoopie pie, blackberry jelly ice cream, peanut butter mousse (OMG, so good), and fresh berries. The chocolate covering the whooiee pie was so decadent, and I loved all the flavors on the updated classic. "It tastes like the Fourth of July," Elle added, saying it reminded her of all-American flavors from the summer holiday.  We were stuffed, but then were surprised with dessert number two: Pineapple Upside-Down Cake served skillet-style ($9), wish medjool date ice cream atop salted caramel.  We devoured every bite despite our full bellies, and every serving was a winner for these two ladies.  While most of what we ordered was vegetarian, Blue Hound's latest menu has some notable seafood items, including Crispy Salt N' Pepper Shrimp, Grilled Yellowfin Tuna and Red Snapper.
